prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
Aita for giving a woman a taste of her own behavior
I'm sitting at the airport and this older lady sat down right next to me and took her iPad out and starts watching a show quite loud. 

To me this is a foul in public however I just ignored it and put my earbuds in. 

After a while I made a phone call using my earbuds. Literally 30 seconds into my call she interrupts me and asks me to quit being rude and talk quietly so she can hear her show.

I was as polite as I could and said that not only herself but everyone for about 10 feet and I could hear her show word for word and that making a phone call isn't rude but watching a show on your device full volume in a public waiting area is actually very rude and that is why people use headphones. 

She said she has every right to enjoy her show without being interrupted by a rude and selfish phone call or having to use headphones. 

I said she was absolutely right and I am completely wrong, please enjoy your show while we  wait for the plane and I will do  the same.       I then proceeded to take out my iPad and open ice cubes good cop bad cop music video and play it full volume on my device without my earbuds. 

I have never seen someone storm off so mad. 


"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the author of the story is in the wrong. So the situation is at an airport: an older lady sits next to the author, watches a show loudly on her iPad. The author initially ignores it and uses earbuds. Then, when the author makes a phone call with earbuds, the lady interrupts and asks him to be quiet. The author responds politely, pointing out that her behavior is actually rude. She claims she has the right to enjoy her show, and the author then plays a music video full volume, leading her to storm off.

Hmm. The first thing to consider is the norms in public spaces. Generally, people are expected to use headphones for audio to avoid disturbing others. The lady was watching a show loudly, which is considered rude. The author, using earbuds, then makes a phone call, which is reasonable because earbuds would muffle the sound. But the lady gets upset and tells him to stop. The author's response is to mock her by playing loud music, which escalates the situation.

So, the key points here: Did the author act in the wrong by retaliating? The lady was indeed being inconsiderate by not using headphones. The author had a valid point. However, retaliating by playing loud music himself could be seen as equally rude. Even though the author was defending his right to make a call with earbuds, his response might be excessive. 

But the question is whether he is in the wrong. The lady's behavior was wrong, so the author was correcting her. However, his retaliation—playing loud music full volume—might not be justified. Just because someone else is being rude doesn't give you the right to respond with the same behavior. It's a tit-for-tat approach, but that could be considered inappropriate in public. 

Also, the author said he was wrong and then proceeded to do the same as the lady. That's a bit of a contradiction. If he acknowledged his own rudeness, but then chose to play loud music, that's hypocritical. Even if his initial reaction was correct, the way he handled it might have been wrong. 

So the answer would be A (Yes, the author is in the wrong) because while the lady's actions were rude, the author's retaliation was also rude and not the appropriate response. Instead of matching her behavior, he should have tried to de-escalate or perhaps spoken to her more calmly. Retaliation with loud music isn't a good solution.
